messageBody:
And speaking of private methods, I've extended JUnit on a number of
occasions and have had to jump through hoops because some methods that I
thought should really be public are private. I come from a Smalltalk
background where everything is public. You make things private through
what is effectively a comment. I like this because you don't throw
arbitrary limitations on people who want to use or extend your
frameworks but you do let them know that certain methods are subject to
change in the future so they can manage risk accordingly.

Tying this to my append below, if you publish APIs via Interfaces and
make methods in concrete classes public, indicating which methods are
really likely to change or go away via comments, others are free to
extend the concrete classes as much as they see fit and assume as much
risk as they feel comfortable with.

> Private methods are difficult to test because, after all,
> they're private. If you adopt a convention that API methods
> are only presented via Java Interfaces instead of concrete
> classes then you don't care about the way the implementers of
> the Interfaces are written. You can then make non-API methods
> within the concrete implementation public without implying
> that they are themselves API methods.
>
> You would also write your API tests for the Java Interfaces
> and plug in the concrete implementations to test them. If you
> need to write tests for lower-level supporting methods within
> the concrete classes you can do that separately, as
> appropriate and its easy because they are public.
>

> > > Private methods support public methods. Therefore well
> > tested public
> > > methods will include the behaviour of the private methods.
> > >
> > > There is no real reason for directly testing private methods.
> > >
> >
> > Domain objects support the GUI. By the logic above a well
> > tested GUI will include the behavior of the domain objects,
> > so there is no reason to unit test the domain objects :-)
> >
> > I've occasionally found reason to write unit tests for
> > private, supporting methods. Often you loose efficiency
> > testing supporting methods indirectly via their caller - such
> > as in the case where you want to test their ability to
> > properly handle a range of input values.
> >
> > Personally, I don't believe in private methods. I'd rather
> > make everything public and testable and expose real APIs via
> > Java Interfaces.
> >
